content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I have endless space and although I liked it I didn't really give enough time to fully enjoy it. Lots of people say this is endless space in a fantasy setting. I disagree. Although some of the mechanics are similar this game is different. Its also different and a lot more fun than many other fantasy based 4X titles. So far I am into my first game and practically did not stop for 14 hours. Yes this game does an excellent job of keeping you in it. The game has a brief tutorial which does a great job of familiarising you with the basics. At first the game does appear a bit daunting with so many options and things to remember. After a couple of hours I became comfortable and then everything just seem to get better as my Empire slowly came to life. Breaking my 4x tradition I decided to start with a faction thats focus is on economy. I have to say  its really been good. It makes a change to buy your way to success instead of relying on churning out a constant army. With this faction I buy my army and its ready in an instant. The game consists of several varied and interesting major factions and then you have numerous minor factions.  Whichever major faction you choose they will have their own unique background story and quests.Units vary but are basically broken down into heroes, support, infantry, cavalry, ranged and flying. You can even make your own units. To conquer regions you need cities and growing your city is a long process. In fact as your research grows you will enter several different ages unlocking even more ablities for the city. As well as battles this game is very much about resource management. I love the way every single hex in the game produces some kind of resource in different quantities. This makes it especially important when deciding where to place your city.This game is pretty much all about time and planning. I really like it that at the beginning of the game you will be in whats known as a 'cold war' with all the other factions. At this stage there can be no peace treaties and you are quite exposed if you end up next door to an aggressive neighbour. Diplomacy in endless legends takes a long time to bear fruit. One thing I do like about the AI on easier settings is that it doesn't tend to attack you the moment it stumbles across you. I've played too many 4X's in the past where you literally get jumped on by the AI before you have started. The great thing about endless is that you start off with a limited number of diplomatic options. The others only come later if you research them. All the other AI factions in the game behave in a specific way. Some are expansionists while others are pacifists. This becomes apparent over time when you see how the factions behave towards each other and the size of their territory.On to the map. Its one of the best and most intuitive I've seen in a 4x. Randomly generated hex landscapes with varied environments from cold wastes to desert. Each will effect how units interact with it. Scattered across the landscape are numerous weird anomalies, exploitable resources, explorable ruins and minor factions. At any point you can smoothly zoom right in and out of the map to get an overview of the empires. The map is big and takes a long time to fully explore. Minor factions play a role in that you need to pacify them early or they will become a threat with their wandering armies. You can even assimilate a limited number of pacified factions which will give you access to one of their units.Battles are fought on a zoomed in version of the region it takes place on. Then its a simple turned based hex battle which goes through a number of phases before the outcome is decided. The environment your units are in at the time will have an effect. Some may think the battles are too simplified with limited options and no spell books like with HoMM games. To be honest I think it works just fine for endless. After a battle if you win your units will earn experience points and gradually level up. This makes keeping veteran armies alive essential for the later game.The music score is superb and blends into the game perfectly.There is a lot more to this game than what I have touched on in this review. Be sure that once its got your attention you will be sinking endless hours into it.10/10

Early Access Review
								It's not finished. It's far from finished actually, though it already looks polished. In fact, I'm pretty sure it's still in Alpha as of writing this.However, the game has already seen a lot of growth and looks good enough to play anyways. There are parts of the game that still need balancing, such as military numbers, happiness, and well... a good number of things basically. However, it is very clear that the team behind this game is in it for the long haul, and it is evident they care a lot about their customers, including updates about ongoing progress to future updates to the game.I don't expect updates every four weeks. I expect updates that have meat behind them and that builds onto the game, especially for an Early Access Game. Even though I haven't played it for hours on end, I can feel it. Even before this game goes into final release, I will be fully addicted to it by Beta.For those who are looking for fast paced gameplay or a simplified tactical play, this is not your game. For those looking for a magitech take on Civilization with turn based tactical combat, story mode, and even RPG elements including upgrading heroes with weaponry and abilities, this is the game you should keep a very close eye on during development.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Endless Legend took me by surprise. I have been a huge Civilization 5 player, with 263 hours on file at the moment, and my heart had always belonged with that game. I recently found interest in Endless Legend and purchased it and I think its a game that every fan of the 4x genre should play or at least look into. Pros:1. Beautiful, intriguing world. Tons of inventive lore infused throughout the game.2. Emphasis on effective empire management. City-building, economy balancing, and researching the tech-circles are really fun. There is also a great emphasis on resource management, each worker you unlock can be placed in different points of emphasis for more resource gain. If you are play a science victory you may want more workers placed in science production to research quickly. If you are playing a supremacy race you may be more interested in placing your workers in industry so you can build units/city expansions quicker, etc...3. Combat is done nicely. You can choose to tactically face your opponent in a way that sort of reminds me of Heroes of Might and Magic. It is turn-based and there may be some strategy. If you don't like that you can choose to spectate and watch the computer make your moves for you or you can just auto-resolve and move on. If you auto-resolve or spectate, you can choose for the computer to be aggressive or passive as well. You can also upgrade units with new weapons that you can craft through the research tree, or find in quests.4. Different factions that actually play quite differently. Some factions just simply cannot do certain things. Such as the necrophage, they can't create peace treaties. They are simply a faction that is meant to kill everything. Playing as the necrophage you may want to push all your workers into industry in order to build your improvements/milita quicker. Playing as the ardent mages you may want to move your workers into science production so that you can rush through the research tree and race to a science victory. There is even a faction that relies solely upon Dust (the games gold currency).4. Some innovative features that haven't been seen in 4x genre. For example: race-specific quest lines that actually serve as a unique victory condition, seasonal effects (summer/winter), the concept of regions limiting city placement, reinforcements, how heroes are handled (as generals or governors), etc., etc.5. The seasonal affects may actually impact some factions play. I know that whenever I enter the winter my production slows greatly. I end up losing roughly 60 gold per turn and most of the units can only move 1 space or so. 6. You can assimilate with minor factions and build/upgrade their units once you acquire them. They also have bonuses that they will provide to your city once you control them.7. The artstyle is very intriguing.8. It isn't like other 4x titles. In fact it does a very good job at seperating itself from other 4x titles (civ 5, age of wonders, etc..)9. You can create your own factions with all the different perks and army units that are provided in the base game. So if you don't like the factions that are in the game you can customize your own from the bottom up.Cons:1. A.I. is kind of bad with certain factions. With the Drakken they are really strong but with some of the other factions they act kind of stupid. This is the game's greatest downfall. But with the modding community helping this out and patches still being worked on (i think) this will come to an end hopefully.2. It would be cool if there were more factions. I'm sure there are other factions you can download through mods but it would've been cool to see more than just 9 factions in the base game.3. To some this is a con: The game is not as easily learned as something like Civ 5. Each turn you have to remember where your units were, you have to remember which direction they were heading, and what they were doing. There is more micromanaging in this game with emphasis on what workers produce which things. There are some things you may even have to wiki as well. There is a lot of things you will just learn the more you play considering the game doesn't really hold your hand at all. Even the tutorial is very basic and doesn't quite go over everything you will face in the game itself.Summary:When i play this game i instantly compare this game to an RPG. There are very many RPG like elements that are fused with the 4x style and this game does it VERY well. The artstyle is very unique and the way it plays is somewhat similar to what HeroScape was like back in the day. In my opinion it is more smooth that Civ 5 and there is more thought that is required within each turn. There aren't many situtations where you will just sit there and continuously hit the end-turn button. There is always a goal in each turn whether it is working towards the factions quests, trying to parley and assimilate with a minor faction, or expand. Yes, the AI needs improvement, but overall I think this is a great game. I wouldn't even say that the AIs mistakes are as noticeable as some of the other strategy games that exist. Playing on higher difficulties even create a loss more often than not so I think that creates a nice challenge sometimes.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Endless Legend is a lot of fun, but I definitely don't recommend it for folks who are new to 4x games. I feel bad drawing such a blunt comparison, but Endless Legend is basically like Civ 5 if Civ were set in a fantasy-themed universe rather than the "real" world. While I am truly in love with EL's music, art, and lore, the actual game mechanics it can be a bit tiresome and over-complicated; especially when you are new to the game. Even though I enjoyed my time with EL, it's not really a game that I return to often, and things feel a bit...empty, particularly in late-game. Still, though, I recommend this game. It's a bold departure from the themes a lot of 4x games try to use and it's a good continuation of the Endless franchise/story. And it's definitely a lot of fun to play in multiplayer mode! Having a friend or three with you for the ride makes this game a lot more enjoyable. (As opposed to Civ, where I find the addition of other players to generally be cumbersome)

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Amplitude Studios is on a roll with this and Dungeon of the Endless. Endless Legend really sucked me in whereas I bounced off of Civ 5 and Endless Space for the most part. With EL they've made the world really come to life. Their use of faction quests, writing, and lore is brilliant in the way it marries a traditional campaign mode with your standard random map skirmish mode. The combat is one of the better approaches for 4x games - just enough player input and control to make it interesting and it never drags so much that you feel like auto-skipping all of it by mid to late game. There's also lots of RPG elements in levelling up and perking up your heros and kitting out your troops with advanced weaponry, items, armour, etc. Tons of customization options.The factions themselves all have their own unique story and playstyle - some of them, like the Cultists and Roving Clans play radically different than most 4x factions. The economy and tech tree and city management has huge depth. Tons of strategic possibilities and paths to victory. It is a bit of a slow burn but the music and artstyle and UI all make it a place you don't mind losing hours to.

												I didn't know that i like 4x games until i played Endless Legend. This game doses 3 things really well. 1. Gameplay and Factions. There are 8 different factions in this game. Each faction plays different than the others. For example there is a faction that can not make peace with others ever. Or there is a factionthat gets a cut off of the market, because it controlls the market (lorewise). 2. Lore and GameplayWhat leads me to my second point. The gameplay is connected to the lore of the game. The lore itsself is very rich and for fans it is also connected to the other Endless games, likeEndless Space and Dungeon of Endless. 3. Gameplay mechanicsIts interface and game design is simple and complex at the same time. But it is simple enough to be able to learn the complex stuff as you play the game over and over. I never got into CiV 5. I just didn't get it. Now that i played Endless Legend i finally know what these 4x games are all about. That game got to be my game of the year 2014 period.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Amplitude Studios is on a roll with this and Dungeon of the Endless. Endless Legend really sucked me in whereas I bounced off of Civ 5 and Endless Space for the most part. With EL they've made the world really come to life. Their use of faction quests, writing, and lore is brilliant in the way it marries a traditional campaign mode with your standard random map skirmish mode. The combat is one of the better approaches for 4x games - just enough player input and control to make it interesting and it never drags so much that you feel like auto-skipping all of it by mid to late game. There's also lots of RPG elements in levelling up and perking up your heros and kitting out your troops with advanced weaponry, items, armour, etc. Tons of customization options.The factions themselves all have their own unique story and playstyle - some of them, like the Cultists and Roving Clans play radically different than most 4x factions. The economy and tech tree and city management has huge depth. Tons of strategic possibilities and paths to victory. It is a bit of a slow burn but the music and artstyle and UI all make it a place you don't mind losing hours to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Endless legends is a game unlike any I have played before. It begins much in the way a game of civilizaiton would, you place a capital and branch out to new cities through the use of settlers, conquests, bribes, and even an intriguing quest system. If you enjoy games like civilization revolution then you will love this unique twist and style that endless legends brings to the genre.While this game is one of the best games of the genre it does have its draw backs. Throughout my play through I began to notice a few irritating things that I feel are necessary to understand about this game before purchase. My first point would be to say that this game is not one that encourages variety. Every faction has three basic units that are unlocked fairly early on, and then they are allowed to assimilate a few minor factions along the way in order to broaden their unit scope. While this may not seem like a big deal to many people it does put certain factions at a major disadvantage against experienced players. My most recent encounter with this is that the Mezari start the game with ranged units that are able to move and shoot all in the same turn, this allows them to kite early game fights and put almost all other factions into the dirt early game. While this may seem like something that many people see as counterable you have to realize that certain factions such as the drakken and the broken lords have no way of countering a ranged unit as they have no late game ranged units of their own without using a valuable assimilation slot.While this game does have its flaws, it is almost impossible to pass up. Its unique quest system sets it apart from the other titles in this genre, as you now no longer have to build a final building but instead with each faction you are encouraged to follow a specific path that will also allow you win the game. Knowing these paths for each faction you are offered a very interesting way of now denying your allies victory, without having to declare war. We also see the hero system in this game help to further its path to the top of my list of most played games. This game rewards those who use its heroes correctly, offering multiple skill tree paths and roles for heroes. A fully leveled hero in this game could be the difference maker in a battle, as a support hero might be what is needed to keep one militia group alive against multiple titans.I strongly recommend this game to any lovers of the civilization series, it sticks to the basic city building aspect of the civ series, all the while giving a unique spin on the battle system and diplomacy system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												8/10I love the concept behind this game. It's kind of like playing Civilisation V but it has so many unique features that it does kind of feel like a different game altogether. At first, going in with this perspective - I have to admit, I didn't like it. It felt a bit like a poor rip off of the game. Delving into it and giving it a chance anyway, I found that actually I like it quite alot. There are certain aspects from the whole territory dividing feature which gives it a unique twist, a restriction that can be described as welcome (otherwise acquiring resources would be not nearly as challenging) to things like being able to customise your own race. This feature is probably one that is not liked by others, and I can't imagine how it would fare if you played for serious competitivity but between friends - feels like a nice little charm seeing the different strategies that your friends will implement to succeed, whether it be from the quite commonly seen choice of tweaking a class that has already been described by the game itself as Broken or from doing something slightly creative and creating a peace loving clan that unites itself in peace with all bar one to single that clan out and abolish them from the game.(Note to Creators should you ever read this: Please don't ever balance this. I don't mind that it is clear that some races have a typical advantage because that creates creative solutions as to how to overcome them - and I always have found games where balancing happens too frequently to become very bland and lack excitement. That moment when you discover something really cool about a race that gives you a clear advantage over others can really contribute to that feeling of something special when playing any game).The music is brilliant, and has an atmospheric aura that only contributes to the game - I am a fan of the originally created audio in most games, my friends however - not so much. But even they have stated that this game doesn't have one of those repetitive audio tracks that begin to get on your nerves after a while but actually can be listened to and enjoyed throughout the playthrough of the game.The graphics are a lovely touch as well, they update every time you re-tab into the game which is great and they look and feel great. They really contribute again to the atmosphere that you're playing in a war as opposed to some kind of arcade themed strategy game. They clearly have had quite some time put into them too and it's a nice touch - even better that you can play the game with these graphics even on a lower spec computer like my own without experiencing too many issues.One problem I do have with the game though (well actually two, a minor and a major). The syncing issue in multiplayer (being the minor problem) can be a little annoying sometime. I have recently learned that this is likely due to the spec of my computer and so isn't too great an issue but I've noticed for some reason it flags off as unsynced but we can still play for ages anyway. I don't mind ignoring and haven't rated the score I gave accordingly - but thought I'd mention it anyway.The problem that I marked the score down for was the way the game is mapped? I don't know if that's the correct terminology but basically when you try to assign the moves of some of your units, sometimes you'll have to remouse over the tile you want a few times (only happens sometimes, so not unbearable). I'm not sure if this is related to terrain mapping but it's a little annoying and has caused me to make a few poor choices by accident. The problem with this is it does contribute to giving the game a little bit of a laggy feel sometimes (also noticeable in the main menu selection as well by the way) which is a shame because it's a tiny feature which lets the game down a tiny bit - especially on first impressions, which if I was a different type of gamer, could have caused me to simply reject the game on that impression alone.Overall, the game is amazing though. I don't want to end on a bad note and I only rated it two lower in the hope for an aspiration for improvement from the developers. The game is great and I'm really enjoying it so far. I would like to see more classes, units and technologies, as well as more factions but I guess that's what DLC is for. I eagerly await the expansions.Great game Devs.-DNChaos.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												It took me around three tries to get into this game as at first coming from Civ V it was a little too , over complicated, different and strange but then bam, I seemed to get the hang of it and now I love the mechanics of the game...You just have to give it a go, experiment and make mistakes and you will do that very much so in the beginning. The tech tree is quite complicated and daunting at first, the quest system can be very distracting and it is slower paced game than Civ V. You have heros who can either lead an army or govern a city and all this takes management. There is some similarities with Civ but also big differences. You have heros to level up as well as troops and this is more comlicated than army upgrades in Civ V. You have districts to upgrade. Apart from that you send settlers out to start cities, you can take over enemy cities with armies and you have diplomacy which is different from Civ V.All the races play differently and each has its own quest line. All in all a very good addictive game which once again like civ is one more turn!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Before I type anything else, let me preface this review by saying that the thumbs up I give this game is a very, very hesitant one. Right. Endless Legend is a game by Iceberg Interactive, the strapping folks behind Endless Space. The general consensus for that is while it was a competent 4X with a very good interface, there was very little actual "meat" to be had. And honestly, that's how it feels here. The game itself is like any familiar 4X: you start out with a hero (who can settle your first town), along with a few token soldiers to help you explore the world. Bigger cities mean more gold, and more production, and more research. However, Endless Legend throws a few other things into the mix. Some work, some don't. First, there's the quest system. Every race has their own unique quests, along with rather generic ones that anyone can get. And honestly, most of the quests are rather dull. Usually some iteration of "go to X". Most of them just feel plain unsatisfying to complete, and feel like a chore. Second, there's the Empire Plan mechanic. 20 turns into the game, you get to set an Empire Plan, which gives your civilization buffs depending how many infulence points you have to spare towards the investments. Once again, it was good to see Iceberg experiment with something new in a 4X, but implementation was lacking. The one thing I did really like was the villager system. Villages are small settlements that belong to minor races, and you can recruit their special units through either defeating them in battle or bribing them. It was something that really made me feel like I was building an empire through a foundation of alliances and trade, which is always nice. The biggest problem this game has, and it's something that's hard to quantify, is that the game just feels *slow*. And not because of its demands on the computer, but just the pace of the game itself. Characters, even on the fastest setting, still take forever to lumber across the map and use up their move points, the battle system is largely the same, and there's just no 'snap' like you'd feel in Civ IV, or Gal Civ II, or hell, even Fallen Enchantress.And this last one is a personal thing, but I've always hated the "magic is actually forgotten technology" setting. It just leaves a sour taste in my mouth.You might notice I've said a lot of bad things about this game, but I'm still recommending it. Well, despite its flaws, it's still a rather addictive and competent 4X. It's got its problems, very avoidable ones, but it has a very solid base. If Iceberg's willing to make the effort, they could turn this from a mediocre 4X to one of the greats.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												If you are on the fence about buying this game I'm going to say a couple things first. 1. Check to see if your computer meets the requirements. Double check and triple check it even. I neglected to thinking my computer could run it since it can run a lot of more demanding stuff but turns out it can't so the game crashes a lot at random. I can still play the game but it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to have to watch for crashes and restart the game. 2. You'll get much more enjoyment out of this game if you are already familiar with the Endless Space universe and lore. It's still a fine 4X strategy game but it's not too special if you don't appreciate the Endless Space lore.That being said here's some pro con action.Pros: Excellent soundtrack, keeping in tradition with Endless Space the game is has a very comfy atmosphere with it's musicIt's damn pretty for a 4X game even on low end settings I'm impressed, I'm not sure there's another game out there that compares to this game on the graphics level in the same genre.The AI is challenging but fair, it tends to make some really petty decisions though like "oh I see your army has visited my lands! you're banned from the market now lol" but each enemy empire has unique personalities a la the civilzation gamesAs mentioned earlier the lore and universe of Endless Space is important here and if you can appreciate it you'll get more out of the individual faction quests. The quests overall add something unique to the 4X genre and even though all of the sidequests tend to be random the main quests for each faction adds something cool to do when you're not doing other 4X activities.Also keeping in tradition with Endless Space each of your units are completely customizable, well as far as weapons,  armor and accesories affecting unit stats goes.The cons: AI is basically cheating at higher difficulties, this could be considered a pro depending on how you look at it but I don't really like it.The combat, when you aren't auto-resolving, is a bit shallow. It basically boils down to changing positioning and firing orders each turn and watching two armies' numbers roll against eachother. Also if you build ranged units with maxed out initiative you can't lose really it's kind of disappointing. The only counter to this being beefing up the HP of your units so they can survive a couple combat rounds to get in close. You have all these other stats but really it boils down to initiative vs HP. Overall I really like this game. 7/10 would be higher without the crashes.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This game is one of the better 4x games that I've ever played. Each faction that I have played has been very different from the ones that came before it, both in aesthetics and gameplay. The world is gorgeous, the art is gorgeous, the diplomacy screens are gorgeous. The game has this unique techno-fantasy feeling going on.Focus of the game seems to be more on the building than on the heroes, so on the 4x spectrum I would place it closer to civilization than to something like HOMM. The game is a fantasy setting, but there is barely any magic so it also doesn't exactly have the feel of Master of Magic or other fantasy 4x games. Large cities sprawl across the land in a satisfying way, reminding me of what Elemental tried to do but failed at.Combat is different than other 4x games I've played. It is kind of a tactical/real time hybrid. Each fight is six rounds of issuing orders to your units and then watching the orders resolve. Sometimes the way things play out make slower units unable to carry out their planned orders, so a wrench can be thrown into your movement/attack orders.I've been playing on standard settings and each game takes about six hours or so. The time just flies away. It's just so damned immersive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I've played a lot of strategy games over the years and this is one of the better ones. A lot of 4x games (not including space 4x) tend to be heavily modeled after the Civilization series, not Endless Legend though. This game is very much its own game.Pros:Each Faction plays very differently from each other. Necrophages can't have peace or alliances, Broken Lords don't need food. Drakken can force peace upon another player, Roving Clans can't declare war etc. Each faction truly is a vastly different playstyle.The game is beautiful. A minor thing that just makes it more enjoyable.The battle system is interesting. More in depth than Civ's smack two units against each other, but not as in depth as Age of Wonders 3 where you control each unit on the battle field.The world is very diverse and there are quests, ruins, minor factions etc. that make exploring both profitable and enjoyable.Unit Customization. You can alter your units with different armor, weapons and trinkets to suit your needs. You take a basic unit from your faction (or assimilated minor factions) and equip them with different equipment to make them stronger or more specialized. For instance you could have a lance weilding Stalwart that does a lot of damage, or one that can take as much damage as you throw at it.Heroes: Strong units that lead armies or govern cities. Very useful and very cool.Mixed:The region system is somewhat strange. When you settle a region with a city, you own that whole region. However, only the tiles directly around your city are worked. You also can only found a single city per region. This means that many areas that would make excellent cities are wasted. On the other hand all the strategic and luxury resources in the region can be harvested by the single city. You also don't get AI settling right next to your city to steal a resource like in Civ.Cons:Limited number of Units. Each faction only has 4 base units. You can assimilate different minor factions for their units but there is a limited number of slots to do this. Compared to other games there aren't many units around. However each faction has three unique units (the settler is common to almost all the factions).AI can travel into your territory automatically and can attack your units outside of your territory without declaring war. You have to declare peace for them not to be able to attack your units and declare closed borders to keep them out of your territory. Both of which cost influence.Declaring war costs influence. Severely annoying and pointless. The other diplomatic stuff makes sense. This does not. You don't need to influece someone to declare war, you just attack them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												About a year ago I bought Civ 5 and fell in love with the game. I found myself playing all the time and seeming to never get bored with it. Eventually though I managed to play it into the ground and had to set it aside. Beyond Earth did not evoke the same feelings that Civ 5 did and I have stayed away from the whole genre until now. Let me say this: Endless Legend looks like what I had always hoped the successor of Civ 5 would look like. If you took Civ 5 and expanded on and improved every aspect you would get something very much like this game. The world is beautiful, the combat is tactical and far more dynamic than civ because of fully customizable units, the different factions are actually DIFFERENT with their own units and distinct playstyles. The only thing that is a little disappointing to me is the lack of noticable difference in gameplay as you advance through the tech trees. Your economy gets much stronger and unit stats go up but you are still using the same units, whereas in civ you go all the way from crude stoneage weapons to a modern military with an airforce and nuclear weapons. I suppose that is the result of having a game take place in a fantasy universe. That aside, however, the game is very fun and any fan of the civ series shouldn't think twice about buying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												My very first 4X game, Endless Legend grabbed my attention above Civ V and Beyond Earth by forgoing a real life setting in favor of a fantasy one. In that regard, EL surprassed my initial expectations. The world of Auriga is fleshed out,  rich with lore. and full of curious races and factions to cross.Each of the playable factions contain a seperate story campaign to accomplish, and each play quite differently. Your playthrough with the peacful and democractic Drakken will prove very different from your playthrough with the aggressive Necrophages.Gameplay in EL is saturated, but not to a fault (I'm still learning after all!). There's a decent tutorial, but to really sink your teeth into it you'll need to sit down for a campaign. Fortunately there's plenty of ways to personalize a campaign's difficulty and world. Unfortunately, it can become a chore to learn, as there's an abundance of sciences and unit customization. Some unit passives and build paths can be poorly explained, and it'll take some digging on your part to really understand how you should be playing a faction to its potential.Fortunately there's plenty of guides available. The online experience varies, but the community's proven friendly and helpful through many of my matches.If you've ever been curious to try a 4x strategy game, and are prepared to sink in the time to learn, Endless Legend's distinguished high fantasy setting, easy to grasp mechanics, and variety of campaigns/playstyles will keep you engaged for a long while. Easily worth it while on sale, still a good buy without, this'll eat up dozens of hours before you've experienced all it has to offer.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Endless Legend is a 4x turnbased strategy game with that plays similar to civ5. Just because it plays like the basics of civ5 mean it is civ5, there is in my opinion many more things that this game has then civ5 does. Each faction is totaly unique and plays completly different then the others, they each have their own lore and each unit looks and acts different from another. Each faction has 4 unique units that have different strengths and weaknesses. Also players start with a "hero" which is basically a general from civ5 but that does way more then adding a buff to a unit. There are tons of heros from each faction and each one looks different(heros from same faction has small differences but have different uses) and plays differnetly, one may be used for leading a army by giving it +2 damage while one could be used to govern and town and give it +6 industry. Also every unit can be customized with different equipment to make them stronger as the game goes by, this is simmilar to civ but instead of the unit become a differnet teir(as a musketer becomes and rifleman) the units in this game stay the same except their equipment changes and you can see the difference in appearance do to this change. Also like civ5 there is small factions that are ran by ai, you can add these to your empire by either attacking and defeating them, bribing them, or by completeing quests given by them. Once they join you then you can assimilate them into your empire and then produce their unit that can only be used by assimilating them. The unit is based off that small faction and its appearance is completely differnet to any of the playable factions, there are lots of these small factions that can be conquered by the player. I recomend this game to anyone that loves the Civ games, fantasy or just 4x turnbased strategy game in general.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I've sunk many hours into this game ever since I had to take a few days off after getting sick. I've played through several full games as the different factions and found that each of them is very unique. I'd say that this is the biggest thing that the game has over Civilization V. If you're at all interested I recommend you read up on each of these because it would take too long to explain here. The other two big differences are a quest and combat systems. Unlike Civ5's city state quests, they don't involve racing other factions or killing another city state(there are none). They're a bit more interesting and present some semblance of a story for each of the factions. Of course, there's not much depth to be expected of quests in a 4X game, but they do make the game a bit more interesting. The combat system, on the other hand, isn't very good and is kind of tedious, especially because of the slow animations. So I wouldn't recommend picking this game up just becasuse you like turn-based combat. But still, it's there and does add SOME depth to combat which would otherwise just be RNG-based. I recommend this game, but I'm also not sure if it feels done yet. I've been playing on the 'Hard' difficulty and I've found that diplomacy and other AI behaviors are a bit irrational. I hope this is something that will be addressed in a future patch. I expect it to be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												If you are on the fence about buying this game I'm going to say a couple things first. 1. Check to see if your computer meets the requirements. Double check and triple check it even. I neglected to thinking my computer could run it since it can run a lot of more demanding stuff but turns out it can't so the game crashes a lot at random. I can still play the game but it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to have to watch for crashes and restart the game. 2. You'll get much more enjoyment out of this game if you are already familiar with the Endless Space universe and lore. It's still a fine 4X strategy game but it's not too special if you don't appreciate the Endless Space lore.That being said here's some pro con action.Pros: Excellent soundtrack, keeping in tradition with Endless Space the game is has a very comfy atmosphere with it's musicIt's damn pretty for a 4X game even on low end settings I'm impressed, I'm not sure there's another game out there that compares to this game on the graphics level in the same genre.The AI is challenging but fair, it tends to make some really petty decisions though like "oh I see your army has visited my lands! you're banned from the market now lol" but each enemy empire has unique personalities a la the civilzation gamesAs mentioned earlier the lore and universe of Endless Space is important here and if you can appreciate it you'll get more out of the individual faction quests. The quests overall add something unique to the 4X genre and even though all of the sidequests tend to be random the main quests for each faction adds something cool to do when you're not doing other 4X activities.Also keeping in tradition with Endless Space each of your units are completely customizable, well as far as weapons,  armor and accesories affecting unit stats goes.The cons: AI is basically cheating at higher difficulties, this could be considered a pro depending on how you look at it but I don't really like it.The combat, when you aren't auto-resolving, is a bit shallow. It basically boils down to changing positioning and firing orders each turn and watching two armies' numbers roll against eachother. Also if you build ranged units with maxed out initiative you can't lose really it's kind of disappointing. The only counter to this being beefing up the HP of your units so they can survive a couple combat rounds to get in close. You have all these other stats but really it boils down to initiative vs HP. Overall I really like this game. 7/10 would be higher without the crashes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I have to say that this is the only 4x strategy game that I have really gotten into, and it is seriously worth it!Here's the shortened version:pros:- different races to play as that actually give a lot of diverse gameplay options- each race has its own (interesting) quest-line and (vibrant) history - quests really give you a purpose and a bit of story to drive you forward and keep you engaged with your faction.- combat system takes the best of Civ V and Total War to create a really fun system!- seasons!- relatively simple interface (you probably need to play the tutorial to fully understand it though)- customise your army units- very sassy AI!- beautiful graphicscons:- you can't see exactly how strong an enemy is before you attack (at least, i havent found a way yet)- tutorial is quite heavy, but also worth it so....- cities are a little hard to see clearly as there is a lot of stuff going on...- it is a little buggy and often crashes when I play multiplayer, but not enough to deter me from the game!The long version:What I like most about this game is the sense of real diversity between each 'culture/races/people'. They each have very specific and drastically different ways of playing them. For example you have a race that is a cult - they can't build extra cities so conquering by force is useless, so instead of soldiers they have preachers who spread their influence and 'take over' other players' settlements through spreading their cult. Another clan is basically vermin zombies who don't even have the option of diplomacy - all they can do is attack other players and eat them or turn their enemies into zombies which they can then control. Or a third one is a bunch of metal armours with souls inside them so they don't require any food resources! There is much more than that but they all have advantages and disadvantages that are really well balanced and truly FEEL different and diverse!On top of that the combat system is really interesting. First of all, each race only gets 4 different base units. That's it. But wait for it..... you get to customise them! As you level them up you get access to tier 2, 3 etc items like armour, weapons, and jewelery which all give you different stats which means you can create different units tailored to your own style of play or needs. For example I'm playing with the woodsland people (not their official name) and i have access only to archers at first. But I have created 2 different types of archers through this system - some are better at fighting infantry units whereas my second class is stronger against flying units. And now I also spent a while upgrading all my unit designs so that I can manufacture better units. There aren't THAT many different options, but there are enough to make it diverse and you can have a lot of fun with it. I also just like the ability to upgrade your units instead of simply receiving new units and you don't really know what they do. This way, I really am getting to know my army for once.Secondly, it's not like in Civ V where your units throw javelins from one hexagon to another hexagon or something like that. In battle you have your little units and they each take up 1 square, so you can control each of them individually, at first you need to decide where to place them (they get advantages or disadvantages based on terrain) and then you decide which enemies they attack. It's the same basic concept as in total war, but with less units and turn-based. You're also able to see the stats of your opponents and so can strategise pretty nicely without it taking forever or being overly complicated.The only down side is that you can't really tell the strength of an enemy army until you have engaged in battle with it (which has meant that 1 and a half of my armies has been accidentally wiped out because of that. But i think that is mostly because i had only archers. Because i didn't have access to anything else at that point because i was focusing on production instead of armies.)Finally, quests. I haven't play that many 4x strategy games but I haven't seen quests like these before. And I love them. I tend to play mostly RPGs because I like story and my main concern with 4x games such as Civ V was that I didn't really care about my people. But not in Endless Legend. Oh no. The quests and bits of story you get gives you motivation and a purpose and that is what is keeping me playing this game! And I don't even have time for it! It feels like there is a story happening - you're not just developing your community for nothing, you've got a purpose and i love that!Basically, it's complex, but simple enough to understand - just the way i like my games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This shaping up to the be the 4X game of the year. It's by the same guys who did Endless Space; their experience with the genre really shines through and it's sort of set in the same universe with similar mechanics. There are some areas they struggled with in the previous game; namely diplomacy and procedurally generated areas. The combat is vastly improved over the original Endless Space, and while there are glaring issues still with balance (AIs getting whupped by minor factions) it's all fairly simple to resolve. There's also a superb choice of playstyles, including factions which cannot go to war but have access to anonymous mercaneries, a faction which cannot be "at peace" with anyone, some which are literalyl powered by magical dust and so forth. Worth every penny if version 1 is half the game v0.581 is so far.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												As  a long time Civ player, i was looking for a new 4X to scratch my itch after the somewhat lackluster Civ: Beyond Earth. Endless Legend is a whole other beast from Civ. So while they are botrh 4X, do not buy thinking it'll just be a fantasy Civ game. That being said, it is an extremely satisfying game, with a complexity that i feel is much deeper than most recent Civ games. From the variety in the factions playstyle, to the absolutely beautiful graphics, the game hits on most points in a unique style not seen in any 4X games.It does have it's flaws such as the heroes who seem similar across the board, to the lackluster AI. The AI is forgiveable due to most 4X games lacking a challenging AI. The Heroes will be addressed at some point as well i'm sure as the devs, seem to always be tinkering with little bits here and there.Overall a very enjoyable experience, and IMO the 4X release of the year. If 4X is your type of game, Endless Legend is worth your time to get to know. Learning curve is steep but worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Endless Legend is the 3rd game in the Endless series, and as they say, 3rd Time's the Charm!  Though my next words won't really convey that well.This game is unfinished.Everything feels pretty loosely connected (that was the only way I could describe things).  The UI feels weak and seems too small.  Sometimes enemy armies will come out of nowhere and destroy your city in one turn.  These are problems that can be patched out or updated.  (The camera doesn't move to show you important things like enemy movement etc., so you can feel like you're being left in the dark to vitally important things.)  Also, randomly the game will say a huge error has occured, give you a feedback log for you to do nothing with, and then continues running as normal (unless it then decides your next turn will never start, but a quick Save/Reload solves this).However, despite these faults, compared to Beyond Earth, this is the better game.The 9 factions are all fantastic, look wonderful and have great, unique effects, and each one feels very different!  From the Necrophage which are quite literally incapable of learning any form of peaceful diplomacy and feast on the flesh of the living to the Drakken, draconic beings who adore peace and start the game knowing everyone (and everyone knowing them), it's truly wonderful.  You can even make your own factions from scratch!  Of course, in old Endless-4X style, you can customise your armies with equipment that improves over the course of the game (making your units take longer to produce to compensate), it all balances out very well.  Minor Factions you can assimilate into your army also make for important choices on which lands you take and which places you destroy, for each grants you a passive bonus along with a new unit for you to make (and considering each army can only make 3 different military units, this is vitally important).This game is good, you should buy it, but it does have some rough edges, but nothing you can't fix or get over.  Get ready to learn a lot of new stuff and have plenty of fun!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												At first, Endless Legend looks like Civ 5 put into a fantasy world. While they have several things in common, mostly building an empire through diplomacy, conquest, and expansion, Endless Legend has several features that separates it from Civ 5.First is how different each of the factions feel and how they are played. In Civ 5, the difference between playing differentfactions generally boils down to small percentages. While these can drastically affect the game, you will mostly play the way everyone else does. In Endless Legend, each faction has its own distinctive traits as well as playstyles. One faction can force peace on other factions while another can teleport their units to cities. These differences become even more interesting as you start creating your own factions. In short, if you find yourself playing the Roving Clans after finishing a game with the Necrophages, you probably won't be using the same strategy.Second is the winter season. Periodically, winter rolls around and generally makes the game harder. Exactly what it does varies from game to game, which can provide a whole new set of challenges with each individual game. It also adds a good bit of difficulty. In Civ 5, the only thing that usually keeps your armies at bay are mountains and other rough terrain. While rough terrain is also in Endless Legend, winter will drastically slow an army down and effectively make combat a fairly rare occurence during winters (at least until the mid to late game as you find ways to become immune to winter's effects). As the winters get longer, the game becomes more difficult, with the actions you take during the summer becoming much more important when the next winter rolls around.Third is unit customization. In Civ 5, your units become better as you advance through the research tree and they are generally static throughout save for the upgrades they get when they level up. In Endless Legend, your units each have their own equipment set that you can customize to your liking. If you're looking to make your ranged unit zip across the map while hitting hard, you can give them the equipment they need to do that (after you research it, anyway). Unit customization also allows your army to adapt to the situation at hand. If you find that your army is equipped to handle flyers while the enemy sent in melee and ranged units, you can retrofit your army accordingly (provided they weren't killed off before you got the chance).These are only a handful of the differences between Civ 5 and Endless Legend. Ultimately, if you're looking for a 4X game with some fresh ideas, you'll probably find it in Endless Legend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Endless Legend is a nice take on the 4X genre, and I could summarize it as the child of the Civilization and Age of Wonders series. It's focused on tech research and city building and administration like Civilization but still has the very interesting tactical aspect of combat of AoW; moreover, you still have the possibility to upgrade your current units and heroes with the latest weapons, armor and artifacts you have researched -- a bit like what you can do in Stardock's Fallen Enchantress or in the classic Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.A novel aspect of EL with respect of all the games I've mentioned is that the game map is divided into regions and each region can host upto one town only; this makes things a bit more interesting as the town has to be placed strategically in accordance with which resources the single region has to offer.The graphics style is really appealing to me, and the music (that you get also in MP3 format bundled with the game download for free) really nails the mood and tempo of the game.The only bad thing that I can say about EL is that the AI isn't very challenging at all; sometimes it could just stay idle in its initial territory for the most part of the match -- that's what happened to the Mezari in my first ever game. If this one issue is fixed, EL can become a true classic gem of the genre.My vote: 8.5/10PS: I'm still waiting for the Linux release!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												8/10I love the concept behind this game. It's kind of like playing Civilisation V but it has so many unique features that it does kind of feel like a different game altogether. At first, going in with this perspective - I have to admit, I didn't like it. It felt a bit like a poor rip off of the game. Delving into it and giving it a chance anyway, I found that actually I like it quite alot. There are certain aspects from the whole territory dividing feature which gives it a unique twist, a restriction that can be described as welcome (otherwise acquiring resources would be not nearly as challenging) to things like being able to customise your own race. This feature is probably one that is not liked by others, and I can't imagine how it would fare if you played for serious competitivity but between friends - feels like a nice little charm seeing the different strategies that your friends will implement to succeed, whether it be from the quite commonly seen choice of tweaking a class that has already been described by the game itself as Broken or from doing something slightly creative and creating a peace loving clan that unites itself in peace with all bar one to single that clan out and abolish them from the game.(Note to Creators should you ever read this: Please don't ever balance this. I don't mind that it is clear that some races have a typical advantage because that creates creative solutions as to how to overcome them - and I always have found games where balancing happens too frequently to become very bland and lack excitement. That moment when you discover something really cool about a race that gives you a clear advantage over others can really contribute to that feeling of something special when playing any game).The music is brilliant, and has an atmospheric aura that only contributes to the game - I am a fan of the originally created audio in most games, my friends however - not so much. But even they have stated that this game doesn't have one of those repetitive audio tracks that begin to get on your nerves after a while but actually can be listened to and enjoyed throughout the playthrough of the game.The graphics are a lovely touch as well, they update every time you re-tab into the game which is great and they look and feel great. They really contribute again to the atmosphere that you're playing in a war as opposed to some kind of arcade themed strategy game. They clearly have had quite some time put into them too and it's a nice touch - even better that you can play the game with these graphics even on a lower spec computer like my own without experiencing too many issues.One problem I do have with the game though (well actually two, a minor and a major). The syncing issue in multiplayer (being the minor problem) can be a little annoying sometime. I have recently learned that this is likely due to the spec of my computer and so isn't too great an issue but I've noticed for some reason it flags off as unsynced but we can still play for ages anyway. I don't mind ignoring and haven't rated the score I gave accordingly - but thought I'd mention it anyway.The problem that I marked the score down for was the way the game is mapped? I don't know if that's the correct terminology but basically when you try to assign the moves of some of your units, sometimes you'll have to remouse over the tile you want a few times (only happens sometimes, so not unbearable). I'm not sure if this is related to terrain mapping but it's a little annoying and has caused me to make a few poor choices by accident. The problem with this is it does contribute to giving the game a little bit of a laggy feel sometimes (also noticeable in the main menu selection as well by the way) which is a shame because it's a tiny feature which lets the game down a tiny bit - especially on first impressions, which if I was a different type of gamer, could have caused me to simply reject the game on that impression alone.Overall, the game is amazing though. I don't want to end on a bad note and I only rated it two lower in the hope for an aspiration for improvement from the developers. The game is great and I'm really enjoying it so far. I would like to see more classes, units and technologies, as well as more factions but I guess that's what DLC is for. I eagerly await the expansions.Great game Devs.-DNChaos.

												This game is an interesting one for sure. The base game is entertaining to a degree, with it's own uniqueness to similar games of the type. It is set apart by atmosphere provided by an amazing soundtrack, beautiful visuals, and mystical or enchanted events. Once the dlc's come into play; however, Endless legend takes on several new dimensions of gameplay, lore, and frontiers. They add interesting new empires and gamechanging mechanics. They may be perhaps a bit pricy if you have a small budget like me, but it is made up for by the fact that only the host needs the dlc for the entire game to enjoy it's effects and play the expanded game. Definitely worth the money for all the dlc if you end up enjoying the base game alone.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												As a big Civ fan, I was expecting this to be a worse, fantasy take on the series. My first impression didn't do much to change that.However, stick with it. The learning curve is nowhere near as steep as it looks, and the reward is a game that plays like the sort of take on Civ 5 that you wished Beyond Earth would have been. There's depth in areas that Civ is shallow in (specifically, the tactical combat system), and some of the more tacked-on feeling mechanics of Civ have been stripped down to the basics or left on the cutting room floor. It's a leaner, tighter game.Better than Civ? I don't know that I'd go that far. But it's very different, and it's absolutely worth a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This one's a bit of a tough recommendation. If youo're looking for a 4x game with a really intriguing story and a neat take on the 4x formula, this is a great game. Also, be prepared to do a lot of micro managing. If you're into that (as I am) you'll have a lot more fun with it. The story behind each of the 8 playable factions is deep enough to get invested in, but open enough for the player to make their own story out of it. However, there are some very frustrating things with the quest system. Quests are a very important part of the game, but they are by far the weakest part. There are many quests whose completion requirements are overly specific in what is required, and yet strangely general in how they are told. Many times I thought I completed a quest and hadn't because of some minor detail which wasn't fully recounted. For example, one quest required me to grow a city to the size of 8. The city was already at a size of 14, but the quest didn't complete. I had to starve the city down to 7 population, and then re-grow it to get the completion on the quest. Possibly that was intentional, but it was extremely frustrating. Twice, the game actually bugged in such a way that completing a quest was impossible.There have also been more than a few crashes, but the game autosaves every turn so it's not that much of a problem, and with luck that will get fixed in a later patch. Overall, mostly great 4x game that could use a few patches. If the quests are fixed and the crash bugs are removed, this game is very solid.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												GOOD:- Pretty. Sparkly.- Factions play quite differently from each other.- Frequently updated, with an expansion coming soon.- Customizable factions, and lots of world generation options.- Minor factions (think city states) can give you passive bonuses and unique units.- Lots of win conditions.- Reinforces my opinion that winter is the worst season.MIXED:- The combat is weird. You assemble military units into armies, which can be moved around as a group, so you don't have to give orders to each of your fifteen thousand units. Then you smash your armies into other armies. You have very little control over actual fighting, which can be annoying, but if one army is much stronger than the other, you can just auto-resolve the fight to save time.BAD:- UI is too busy, and the text is too small.- No mini-map or strategic mode.- Diplomacy needs major changes, as any agreements you make can be broken immediately. (Market ban rage!!)- Almost nobody is playing multiplayer.- There's no way to tell a city to produce nothing (or just gold/science like Civ). It will nag you every turn.- The AI is mega stupid and unfriendly, even on the easiest difficulty.- The world is split into pre-defined regions, and you can only have one city per region.- Quests are too strict. I've had to raze several of my own cities in order to re-do stuff the quest demanded.- Certain sounds don't behave according to volume settings.- I have a good computer, and yet a duel between me and an AI lags worse than a six person Civ multiplayer game.- No steam workshop at the moment.- Very few characters for city/army names.This sounds like a lot of complaining, but I actually like the game. It just hurts my eyeballs after a while. It's not better than Civ 5, however. If you've never played this sort of game before, seriously get Civ 5 instead. If you've already played Civ and want something new, this is a decent pick up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Cookie cutter, copy paste, same-same.These are all words that have been used to describe many, many 4x strategy games in recent years.For those few that are not in the "know", 4x stands "eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate". In the past the 4x genre was an interesting and innovative hybrid of strategy games. Unfortunately many have been taking the "safe" route. (Read UNinteresting and UNinnovative.)Then Endless Legend walked into the room like a boss, announced that it didn't like the tried and true. It told us that it didn't care what people thought of it.And it truly doesn't, and I love it for that.It brought us many new or semi new features, some that it came up with on it's own, some that it borrowed.The first thing that comes to mind, is the region system.Gone are the days of spamming cities on every open piece of dirt, whether valuable or not, (Cough-Civ series-Cough) Now every section of the vast continents of land is divided up by regions in which only one city may settle upon. Certain factions are even penalized for expanding onto them too quickly.It creates an atmosphere that makes each and every one of the cities in your kingdom seem more unique and important.Instead of thinking of it as just another city, now I think of it by its name and history.Speaking of regions, there are a wealth of resources in them, both strategic and luxury that can implemented in different manners. Sell and trade them or use them as boost for different affects. They apply different bonuses for your cities, troops and for you kingdom overall.Resources not enough for you? How about natives? Each region has different native populations that can be assimilated, either by force, bribery or peaceful means. Different species bring interesting boosts to the region and can even be recruited. Ever felt like fielding an army of wolf/human hybrids? Now you can.---All layers of the standard 4x are here, diplomacy, economy, expansion and combat. All are done well.I really enjoyed the diplomacy, and that happens to be a vastly overlooked feature in most strategy games.But not here. My only wish is that many of the features were not locked behind technology research.Now that I mentioned technology, Endless Legends has its own view on research trees. It is rather standard with only a few minor twists, there being 6 different ages, all bringing new technologies to research.Sometimes it seems cluttered and sometimes big decisions must be made. I'm not a huge fan and I hope they rework it through patches.But it's not big enough of a problem to really detract from the game overall.---That's racist.With only 8 different races to choose from, it may sound like their aren't a-lot of options there.But instead of 40 different copy-paste races with a few minor bonuses to switch things up with, Endless legends 8 races all play vastly different from each-other and make each play-through seem like you're playing a different game altogether.In the wise wise words of Lloyd Christmas, "I like it alot".---Troops and heroes. The backbone of every 4x, at first glance it appears that this is one of the down failings of Endless Legend, when in fact it is a strong point.Your standard kingdom only has 4 different soldiers, which sounds like a bummer. That is until you realize that they can be upgraded in many different ways and the aforementioned native and independent troops that can be bought, traded or assimilated into you kingdom. All customizable.True, they aren't as customizable as some games have striven to make theirs, but in Endless Legends, your choices on each piece of gear is strategically important.My only complaint here is that upon equipping a new piece of armor, one cant visibly see a difference in the character sprite, that is slightly disappointing and will hopefully be patched later on.On to heroes! While they can be leveled up, perks and bonuses chosen, extra gear and and gadgets equipped, they seem rather dull.Don't get me wrong, they are very important to a successful army, just the heroes themselves have no real personalities or real distinctiveness, which in a unique game full of personality, it really sticks out like a sore thumb.---Music and graphics.While these two are less important for a strategy game, they really do need mentioning.Rarely have I seen or heard such a beautiful game. The graphics are georgeus and relay a real sense of immersion. I believe this may be the most graphically lush 4x I've ever played.The music is phenomenal. I've never bought a game's soundtrack before, but I will this one.The music is rendered in the up-most quality, I can't say I've heard such a soundtrack since Arcanum. and that is the biggest complement I can fathom.---Overall, I give this game a high recommendation for any fan of 4x strategy games. It managed to pull me deeper than many of its peers in the gaming market. I do not regret this purchase in the slightest, and that coming from a poor man, well that means a-lot.There are some balancing issues here and there, but with Amplitude-Studios track record, it's safe to say that they will be fixed shortly. That and the addition of modding support, the only direction this game is going, is up.I've seen what dedicated moders can do with the proper support and that has the potential to add years and years of playability.If your into 4x and you want something that doesn't come from an assembly line, you couldn't do better than Endless Legends especially for the price.For those poorer gamers like myself, Christmas time at Steam is coming!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												This game got some recent backlash from the Chinese userbase. More details here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/289130/discussions/0/355043117503038170/tl;dr No negative changes to the game itself. Chinese translation mod has pirate link in description, user refuses to remove pirate link, Amplitude utilize Steam TOS to remove mod. Chinese users mad.Phoey to that. I'm excited for the upcoming Tempest expansion, so here's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, brief, said-before review of the game in it's current state: the Shifters expansion.8/10 would recommend.Some good: * Races have mechanical differences. From as simple as starting with certain research techs for free (which goes further than I'd have thought to giving each faction their own feel), to being completely unable to utilize a resource with the trade off of being more adept at exploiting another.* Custom factions. "Oh boy, I wish I could play as the Vaulters but get the ability to assimilate minor factions like the Cultists!" You can! You're given a point budget, a pool of bonuses / penalties (base faction abilities & more generic options), Getting that Cultist ability will cost you points, but if you also adopt penalties, such as a generic hit to a resource, or a race specific such as Dust Lords being unable to utilize Food, you can points back to spend on more bonuses -- probably something to increase your Dust, since now you need to buy your population. And since you can't use Food, you may as well get some points back by penalizing your Food gain .... Some meh:* Combat can take some adjustment, and is sometimes a chore. Each team takes their turn simultaneously, and even though YOUR army gets 'stuck' when an enemy army decides to walk into you, you'll find yourself chasing after a wont-stop-and-engage npc army -- hopefully not running out of movement points before them. Workable, but bothersome. Same for the manual combat - there's a great depth to be found in the different outfitting of your units and compositions of your army, but you'll need to adjust to ordering your troops around. Tip: only give complex orders to units who have initiative higher than the enemy units.* Visibility. This one pains me, because it is so important. If you leave FIDSI (food, industry, dust, science, influence) gains showing all the time, you'll have a lot of trouble seeing the terrain. When you're deploying for manual combat, you might have trouble seeing what tiles you can deploy to. When you're trying to see the borders of your cities exploitations, colors might blend together in a bothersome fashion, and your own city name-plate might get in your way.

												Still one of the best 4X games available on Steam. The world is filled with interesting lore, the soundtrack is a delight to listen to and each one of the available factions are completely distinct from one another. You have one that can't declare wars, another that can't declare peace or alliances, one that is unable to grow food, the other that can't research new technologies so they have to steal it from others... and if you're not happy with any of the factions available, you can just create your own. If there's one thing this game isn't lacking it's depth and meaningful choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												This is a very entertaining 4X games which blends elements from Civilization 5 with its own fantasy setting and take on the genre to create something truly special. Its gotten a ton of content and support from the developer post release and is something I enjoy firing up once in a while for a game or two.While civ5 is my main goto game when I need my 4X itch scratched, Endless Legend is without a doubt the second on my list. There is a great variety of races, play styles and victory conditions to keep you coming back. Lots of great mechanics, interesting setting, great balance and care for the genre makes this a top tier 4X game and is well worth your time and money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												If you like the Civilization series, you will probably like this. Pros- Innovative (looks like Civ VI is taking some pointers from this game)- Satisfying city building (the district system is great)- Beautiful Graphics- Wildly different factions/civs- Interesting combat- Meaningful diplomacyCons- Manual combat is slow and while very interesting, feels unpolished.- Notable learning curve (provides for a lot of potential skill, but it takes some getting used to. Nowhere near as bad as dwarf fortress but way more severe than Civ)- Multi-player is even slower (Sometimes you need to use manual combat and this kills the multi player experience. I would recommend this for solo play. Muli-player just takes too long.)On the whole, I'd recommend this game to fans of strategy games. It may not be the most polished game in some ways, but it is unique, innovative and fun so it's well worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												A fantastic take on the 4x turn based genre, Endless Legend offers an incredible amount of play time for a reasonable price. Mind you, I got it for twenty bucks.Take Civ 5 or similar games, and boost the amount of depth and number of features, then throw in some fantasy elements and you've got Endless Legend. Yeah, it is missing some gameplay features such as naval combat and all that, but the game is still being developed and new expansions are being released.All in all, the game is truely a gem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Endless Legend is not just another 4x game or Civilization (V) rip off. In fact it is a beautiful piece of art that, as oppose to other Games, does not only offer a more challenging gameplay, but thanks to the soundtrack and story, an outstanding atmosphere. While playing Endless Legend you do not only feel the 'need' to win, but to survive. Auriga is dying and you can feel it the more you play it, the more time you spend on the planet and the more winters you outlive. The whole game is being underlined by an excellent soundtrack that perfectly fits into the world where you have to solve quests which might award you with huge advantages towards the other races and change a combats outcome. Speaking of which, it is a bit different to fight your enemies. It is somewhere in between the battles of the Civilization series and Age of Wonders as you have a hero with an army that you can move through the map, but while you are in combat these units are taking their positions on it instead of dragging you into a completely different map. It makes the battles more tactical than in Civilization, but not as overdrawn as in Age of Wonders.The units' design fits perfectly into each faction and they can be modified with new weapons while you explore new technologies, but it does not change their appearance and the units are usually limited to 4 different kinds per race. Every faction offers a unique gameplay. They have various motives (which are usually comprehensible), storylines and therefore individual quests. The heroes of each race have, instead of the ordinary units, different artworks and some of them might only be obtained by finishing quests.The game itself is getting a bit more difficult the more winters you survive as they keep on lasting longer, dropping your production and limiting your units' movement. It is especially outlined by different and beautiful terrains that also offer variant gains. The games' design may remind some players of Endless Space and might confuse you at the first look, but as you spend more time playing it, you learn more things about the resources, units, and advantages as well as disadvantages that come along with every tactical choise you make. Overall this game adds a surprisingly refreshing gameplay which stands out from other 4x games with its charm, beauty, tempo and atmosphere, but cannot completely satisfy with its battles and poor number of units and their slight customization. I would definitely recommend this game to every 4x or strategy games fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This one's a bit of a tough recommendation. If youo're looking for a 4x game with a really intriguing story and a neat take on the 4x formula, this is a great game. Also, be prepared to do a lot of micro managing. If you're into that (as I am) you'll have a lot more fun with it. The story behind each of the 8 playable factions is deep enough to get invested in, but open enough for the player to make their own story out of it. However, there are some very frustrating things with the quest system. Quests are a very important part of the game, but they are by far the weakest part. There are many quests whose completion requirements are overly specific in what is required, and yet strangely general in how they are told. Many times I thought I completed a quest and hadn't because of some minor detail which wasn't fully recounted. For example, one quest required me to grow a city to the size of 8. The city was already at a size of 14, but the quest didn't complete. I had to starve the city down to 7 population, and then re-grow it to get the completion on the quest. Possibly that was intentional, but it was extremely frustrating. Twice, the game actually bugged in such a way that completing a quest was impossible.There have also been more than a few crashes, but the game autosaves every turn so it's not that much of a problem, and with luck that will get fixed in a later patch. Overall, mostly great 4x game that could use a few patches. If the quests are fixed and the crash bugs are removed, this game is very solid.

												This game is really good. It looks like art. I love it.My friend and I played it and I had an issue joining our saved game. We had to use a previous save file for the game to work. When it did work it ran smoothly and even has settings to enlarge the UI for big-screen setups along with a lot of other options to fiddle with.I think this would be a good purchase if you enjoy resource management and RPG elements in a fantasy setting. Definately satisfied with my experience.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was playing a game on easy, I was the Vaulters and I where going for thier recommended victory of science to the max! Later inbt eh game after I and another faction derstroyed the bug faction leaving 2 bots and me to race for victory, by now my empire was on two large islands with another empire in the middle due to me having killed the bug feaction that was on another continent, now I only have one army that runs around killing roaming neutral units one day a ♥♥♥♥ing hug as army of neutral units spawned in the area of my empire where my army was not precent. I only have one army since all of the remaning factions are going for economic science of democratic victory, so I was no prepared to be assaulted by and army of homocidal demons... scuffice to say I lost a third of my empire.But it's early access and I assume the spawn was a bug, the game was GREAT, and I was only expecting it to be okay... the combat is a bit meh but the auto resolve seems to be doing a fair job so it's cool. If you like CIV or AoW you will probably like this one, though you might want to wait for the release because they promise a tutorial by then and I still get confused by things after 4 games all which I left unfinished because I played easy to learn and when you play easy and get ahead there is no real threat except for weird♥♥♥♥♥spawns.
